key_events.description: Petrobras plans to commit $60-70 billion in CAPEX in its 2022-2026 plan, up from $55 billion in 2021-2025.
Petrobras' production guidance was revised upwards, expecting 3.4 million barrels/day in 2029.
Itaú BBA has a buy recommendation with a R$43 price target for PETR4 by the end of 2026. XP Investimentos also has a buy recommendation with a R$37 price target.
Petrobras' proved reserves at the end of 2025 were 12.1 billion boe, up from 11.4 billion boe in 2024.
Last dividend for PETR4 was R$0.34 per share on 2025-12-22, to be paid in 2026-02-20 and 2026-03-20.

risk_factors: Operational risks like the natural decline of production assets

investment_thesis.bull_case: Increased CAPEX focused on subsalt exploration and production, upward revision of production guidance to 3.4 million barrels/day in 2029, and positive analyst recommendations with price targets up to R$43 suggest strong growth potential.
investment_thesis.bear_case: Risks include oil price volatility (below US$65/bbl), CAPEX and OPEX inflation, operational risks, and increased acquisition costs (R$18 billion), which could pressure cash flow and debt neutrality.

summary_markdown: Petrobras (PETR4) shows bullish signals based on increased CAPEX ($60-70 billion in 2022-2026), upward revised production guidance (3.4 million barrels/day in 2029), and positive analyst ratings (Itaú BBA target of R$43, XP Investimentos target of R$37). Proved reserves increased to 12.1 billion boe in 2025. Key risks include oil price volatility (below US$65/bbl), CAPEX inflation, and increased acquisition costs (R$18 billion). The last dividend was R$0.34 per share on 2025-12-22.
